awd_titl_txt: MRI:   Acquisition of controlled-environment chambers for integrative botanical research and training at UT-Tyler
awd_abstract_narration:
This award funds the acquisition of a set of walk-in controlled-environment chambers for plant experimentation. They are equipped with temperature, humidity, photoperiod, lighting, and CO2 controls. Up to 13,500 plants will efficiently fit into these chambers, allowing experiments at all times of the year, including the hot Texas summers. The integrative plant research programs enabled by these chambers will span many sub-disciplines in biology, including cellular biology, molecular biology, developmental biology, physiology, ecology, evolution, and genetics. These chambers will have a stimulating effect on plant biology research throughout Northeast Texas, a region with over one million people that has several universities and colleges but that has almost no facilities for environmentally controlled plant experiments. The primary users for these chambers work with agriculturally important plant families, and their work has either direct or indirect implications for agriculture. Furthermore, the research in these chambers can be conducted under different climate scenarios, including increased CO2 levels and temperatures. 

Undergraduates and graduate students will be allocated space in the chambers to work on these and other projects, providing invaluable training opportunities for future scientists, farmers, and land managers. These findings will be publicized by scientific publications, faculty and student presentations at regional and national meetings, and press releases to local media outlets, which have low barriers to news coverage and large audiences.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit. This award funded the acquisition of a set of walk-in controlled-environment chambers for plant experimentation. They are equipped with temperature, humidity, photoperiod, lighting, and CO2 controls. Up to 13,500 plants efficiently fit into these chambers, allowing experiments at all times of the year, including the hot Texas summers. The integrative plant research programs enabled by these chambers span many sub-disciplines in biology, including cellular biology, molecular biology, developmental biology, physiology, ecology, evolution, and genetics. These chambers have a stimulating effect on plant biology research throughout Northeast Texas, a region with over one million people that has several universities and colleges but that has almost no facilities for environmentally controlled plant experiments besides these ones. The primary users for these chambers work with agriculturally important plant families, and their work has either direct or indirect implications for agriculture. There are also insect users of these chambers working on various projects. The research in these chambers can be conducted under different climate scenarios, including increased CO2 levels and temperatures. Undergraduates and graduate students are allocated space in the chambers to work on these and other projects, providing invaluable training opportunities for future scientists, farmers, and land managers. These chambers are also used for independent classroom projects by students taking various biology courses. These findings are publicized by scientific publications, faculty and student presentations at regional and national meetings, and press releases to local media outlets.

Broader Impacts. The chambers have been utilized by 13 undergraduates working in research labs (six of whom are from minority groups traditionally underrepresented in science, and eight of whom are women) and ten graduate students (four of whom are from minority groups traditionally underrepresented in science, and six of whom are women). These students are working on research projects that they are either leading or are participating in as part of their work with the PI and co-PI. Introductory biology classes and plant biology classes are using the chambers for independent research projects that are part of their laboratory grades. Hundreds of students have utilized the chambers this way. Based on the demographics of the university, we estimate that 10% of these students are African American, 12% are Latino, and 54% are women. The work being conducted on potatoes and palms will potentially impact crop production and thereby increase economic efficiencies. This has tangible potential economic consequences. Furthermore, the work in the chambers is, and will be, directly employing many undergraduate and graduate students, providing them with incomes. The chambers are increasing the research output of UT-Tyler, which will have stimulating economic effects on Northeast Texas by increasing extramural funding and prestige for the university and its collaborating partners, and by providing revenue to local businesses and university employees.
